Mainstreaming Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Change Adaptation

Due to heavy and persistent rains in the first two weeks of January 2013 in the central and southern parts of the country, there were significant damages to infrastructure in Maputo city and in numerous settlements in Gaza Province (Chibuto, Chokwe, Guija, Xai-Xai and Bilene). The flooding was further exacerbated by the high rainfalls upstream in South Africa, Malawi and Zimbabwe, and sudden increments in outflows from those neighboring countries through the main river basins in the south and central parts of the country, namely: Limpopo, Incomati, Inhanombe and Save in the south and (Zambezi, Pungoe and Buzi in the central regions).  Due to the high magnitude and extend of impact of the floods, a red alert was declared on January 12 preceded by an institutional red alert on January 22, 2013 requesting all ministries and development partners to rollout their emergency funds and to further mobilize resources to address the unmet gaps. 
As part of UNDP's mandate during emergencies, being responsible for early recovery processes which begin from the onset of the disaster and coordination, it was crucial for UNDP to take this leadership role to ensure that all sectoral needs are properly addressed.  
The project document was signed in January 2013 focusing on the following Outcome "Sustainable and effective management of natural resources and disaster risk reduction benefit all people in Mozambique, particularly the most vulnerable"
